Salvage Title Guide — What It Means & Should You Buy One?

Everything you need to know about salvage titles: what they are, how vehicles get salvage-branded titles, rebuilt title vs. salvage title, insurance challenges, resale impact, and how to evaluate a salvage vehicle safely.

  2. 2 How a Vehicle Gets a Salvage Title

What Is a Salvage Title?

A salvage title is a legal designation applied to a vehicle that has been declared a total loss by an insurance company. When the cost to repair a damaged vehicle exceeds a certain percentage of the vehicle's actual cash value (typically 75-90%, depending on the state), the insurance company "totals" the vehicle and pays out the claim. The vehicle's title is then branded as "salvage" to permanently indicate its damage history.

A salvage-branded vehicle cannot legally be driven on public roads in most states until it has been repaired, inspected, and re-titled as a "rebuilt" or "reconstructed" vehicle. The salvage brand remains on the vehicle's title history permanently, even after it is rebuilt, meaning future buyers will always be able to see that the vehicle was once totaled.

Salvage titles are not limited to collision damage. Vehicles can receive salvage titles due to flood damage, fire damage, theft recovery (if the vehicle was missing long enough for the claim to be paid), hail damage, or even vandalism. The cause of the salvage brand significantly affects the vehicle's long-term reliability and safety.

How a Vehicle Gets a Salvage Title

The salvage title process follows a specific sequence of events:

  1. Damage occurs. The vehicle is damaged in an accident, flood, fire, or other event.
  2. Insurance claim is filed. The owner files a claim with their insurance company.
  3. Adjuster assesses damage. The insurance company's adjuster determines the cost of repairs and compares it to the vehicle's actual cash value (ACV).
  4. Total loss determination. If repair costs exceed the state's total loss threshold (as a percentage of ACV), the vehicle is declared a total loss.
  5. Insurance pays the claim. The owner receives the ACV of the vehicle minus their deductible.
  6. Title is branded. The state DMV brands the vehicle's title as "salvage" based on notification from the insurance company.
  7. Vehicle is disposed of. The insurance company takes ownership and typically sells the salvage vehicle at auction to rebuilders, salvage yards, or the public.

The total loss threshold varies by state. In some states, it is as low as 75% of the vehicle's value, while others use a "total loss formula" that considers the repair cost plus the scrap value. This means that the same level of damage could result in a salvage title in one state but not another.

Rebuilt Title vs. Salvage Title

Understanding the difference between a salvage title and a rebuilt title is critical:

Salvage title: The vehicle has been declared a total loss and has not been repaired. In most states, a salvage-titled vehicle cannot be legally registered for road use. It can only be sold for parts, scrapping, or repair.

Rebuilt title (also called "reconstructed" in some states): The vehicle previously had a salvage title, has since been repaired, and has passed a state inspection verifying that it is roadworthy. A rebuilt title allows the vehicle to be legally registered and driven, but it carries a permanent brand indicating its salvage history.

The quality of rebuilt title vehicles varies enormously. Some are professionally restored to near-original condition using genuine parts. Others are repaired as cheaply as possible using inferior parts, questionable repair techniques, or mismatched components. The state inspection required for a rebuilt title varies widely in rigor, with some states conducting only a cursory visual inspection rather than a comprehensive structural evaluation.

Risks of Buying a Salvage Vehicle

Buying a salvage or rebuilt title vehicle comes with significant risks that buyers must weigh against the lower purchase price:

  • Hidden structural damage: Even after repairs, underlying structural damage from a collision may compromise the vehicle's crashworthiness. Crumple zones and frame rails that have been bent and straightened do not provide the same level of protection in a subsequent crash.
  • Flood damage consequences: Flood-damaged vehicles are particularly risky because water intrusion can cause slow-developing electrical failures, corrosion of hidden components, and mold growth that may not become apparent for months or years after purchase.
  • Reduced resale value: Salvage and rebuilt title vehicles typically sell for 20-40% less than comparable clean-title vehicles. This reduced value persists for the life of the vehicle, regardless of the quality of repairs.
  • Insurance difficulties: Many insurers will not provide comprehensive or collision coverage for salvage or rebuilt title vehicles, limiting you to liability-only policies. Those that do offer full coverage may require additional inspections and may cap payouts at a reduced value.
  • Financing challenges: Most banks and credit unions will not finance vehicles with salvage or rebuilt titles. Buyers typically need to pay cash or use specialized high-interest lenders.
  • Unknown repair quality: Without detailed documentation of the repair process, you cannot know whether safety-critical repairs were performed correctly. Airbags may not have been replaced, frame alignment may be off, and safety systems may not function properly.

Insuring a Salvage or Rebuilt Title Vehicle

Insurance for salvage and rebuilt title vehicles presents unique challenges:

Liability coverage is available from most insurers for rebuilt-title vehicles, as it covers damage you cause to others rather than to your own vehicle.

Comprehensive and collision coverage is harder to obtain. Some insurers will not offer it at all for rebuilt-title vehicles. Those that do may require a detailed inspection and photographs documenting the vehicle's current condition. The payout for a total loss will be significantly less than for a comparable clean-title vehicle.

Insurers that commonly cover rebuilt-title vehicles include Progressive, GEICO, and some regional carriers. Always disclose the title brand when obtaining quotes, failure to do so could void your coverage.

Tips If You Decide to Buy

If the price discount is compelling enough and you are comfortable with the risks, follow these steps to protect yourself:

  1. Run a comprehensive VIN history report. Use Car Alpha's VIN lookup to check for recalls and decode specs. Also obtain a full vehicle history report to understand the nature and extent of the original damage.
  2. Determine the cause of the salvage brand. Hail damage and minor cosmetic damage are far less concerning than structural collision damage or flood damage. If the cause cannot be determined, proceed with extreme caution.
  3. Obtain all repair documentation. Ask the seller for detailed records of all repairs performed, including parts used, the repair facility, and before/after photographs. Reputable rebuilders document their work thoroughly.
  4. Get an independent pre-purchase inspection. Pay a qualified mechanic or a body shop with frame measurement equipment to inspect the vehicle thoroughly. This is even more critical for salvage vehicles than for clean-title used cars.
  5. Check for frame damage. Have the frame measured against manufacturer specifications. Any deviation indicates inadequate structural repair.
  6. Test all safety systems. Verify that all airbags are present and functional (the airbag warning light should illuminate briefly at startup and then turn off). Test all seatbelts, ABS, and stability control systems.
  7. Negotiate aggressively. Rebuilt-title vehicles should sell for 20-40% below comparable clean-title market value. Do not pay near clean-title prices for a vehicle with a salvage history.

Title Washing — The Hidden Danger

Title washing is an illegal practice where a salvage or branded title is "cleaned" by re-titling the vehicle in a state with less strict title branding laws. The vehicle then appears to have a clean title, hiding its damage history from unsuspecting buyers.

To protect yourself from title washing:

  • Always run a comprehensive vehicle history report that checks records across all 50 states.
  • Be suspicious of vehicles with titles from states far from where they are being sold.
  • Look for signs of prior repair work during your physical inspection.
  • Check the National Motor Vehicle Title Information System (NMVTIS) for complete title history across state lines.
  • If a deal seems too good to be true, it often is. A suspiciously low price on a seemingly clean-title vehicle warrants additional investigation.
